conclusion: The problem involves two velocity-time graphs for objects A and B moving in the same direction along a straight line.
The question asks if the difference in speed between the two objects is continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1.
A velocity-time graph has time (t) on the x-axis and velocity (v) on the y-axis.
Both objects start from time 0 and reach time t1. Object A has a higher velocity than object B throughout this time interval.
There's a red line labeled 'Difference' at a certain point, representing the difference in their velocities at that particular time.

premise: To determine if the difference in velocity increases, consider the slopes of the curves.
conclusion: The slope of a velocity-time graph represents the acceleration of the object.

premise: The difference in velocity between A and B at any time t is given by: Difference(t) = v_A(t) - v_B(t).
conclusion: The slope of this difference curve would give the difference in acceleration between A and B.

premise: The derivative of difference(t) with respect to time t is: difference'(t) = v_A'(t) - v_B'(t) = a_A(t) - a_B(t).
conclusion: The sign of difference'(t) depends on the difference between a_A(t) and a_B(t).
Both curves are symmetric about a vertical line somewhere in the middle.
Object A reaches its peak velocity before object B.
Both curves start at the origin and return to zero velocity at time t1.

premise: Assuming both curves are parabolic, object A has a higher peak velocity and reaches it earlier than object B.
conclusion: For a parabolic velocity-time curve, the acceleration is linear in t.

premise: If v(t) = c*t*(t - t1), it gives a parabolic shape with roots at t=0 and t=t1.
conclusion: This suggests that v(t) is quadratic in t, and thus a(t) is linear in t.

premise: The difference in speed between the two objects is the difference in their vertical coordinates.
conclusion: The speed difference first increases and then decreases.
